description: From Middle English conceyte, formed from conceyven by analogy with pairs such as (Modern English) deceive~deceit, receive~receipt etc. Doublet of concept and concetto. Akin to Portuguese conceito.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Something conceived in the mind; an idea, a thought. [14th–18th c.]
The faculty of conceiving ideas; mental faculty; apprehension.
Quickness of apprehension; active imagination; lively fancy.
(now rare, dialectal) Esteem, favourable opinion. [from 15th c.]
(countable) A novel or fanciful idea; a whim. [from 16th c.]
examples: Tasso […]  is full of conceits  […]  which are not only below the dignity of heroic verse but contrary to its nature.

entries.meaning: (countable, rhetoric, literature) An ingenious expression or metaphorical idea, especially in extended form or used as a literary or rhetorical device. [from 16th c.]
(uncountable) Overly high self-esteem; vain pride; hubris. [from 17th c.]
examples: Plum'd with conceit he calls aloud.

verbs.description: conceit (third-person singular simple present conceits, present participle conceiting, simple past and past participle conceited)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To form an idea; to think.
examples: Those whose  […]  vulgar apprehensions conceit but low of matrimonial purposes.
That owls and ravens are ominous appearers, and presignifying unlucky events, as Christians yet conceit, was also an augurial conception.
